title: Western Union Telex, TWX, and Time Service
historical_context: This article discusses the historical significance of Western Union's telecommunication services, particularly Telex and TWX, as well as their time service, which played a crucial role in synchronizing clocks before the advent of modern technology.
target_audience: Hackers, telecommunications enthusiasts, and those interested in the history of communication technology.
short_summary: The article provides an in-depth look at the history and functionality of Western Union's Telex and TWX services, as well as their time service, which synchronized clocks across various locations. It highlights the technological evolution and eventual decline of these services.
summary:
In this article, Phone Phanatic delves into the operational intricacies of Western Union's Telex and TWX systems, which were once ubiquitous in business communications. The author explains the differences between the two systems, detailing how they functioned over dedicated phone lines and their unique dialing protocols. The piece also touches on the historical context of Western Union's dominance in the messaging space, particularly before the rise of digital communication technologies. The decline of these services is noted, as they transitioned from a robust network to a mere shadow of their former selves due to technological advancements and changing market demands.

Additionally, the article explores the Western Union Time Service, which provided synchronized timekeeping for businesses before the widespread adoption of alternating current. The author describes the mechanics of the self-winding clocks used in offices and how they were calibrated by master clocks, ensuring accurate timekeeping across various locations. The nostalgic tone captures the significance of these services in the past, culminating in the discontinuation of the Time Service in 1965, which led to a rush for the historical clocks by employees. This article serves as a valuable historical account of telecommunication practices and their evolution.
